title: Rate of formation of carbon dioxide

content.question:
<math alttext="C a C O 3 solid plus 2 H with a positive one charge aqueous react to produce C a with a positive 2 charge aqueous plus H 2 O liquid plus C O 2 gas " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

Experiment 
Initial Mass of <math alttext="C a C O 3 solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> <math alttext="in grams " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>grams</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> 
Initial Concentration of <math alttext="H with a positive one charge aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="in molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>M</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> 
Initial Temperature of Reactants <math alttext="in degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

The initial rate of formation of <math alttext="C O 2 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> from the chemical reaction represented by the equation above was studied in two separate experiments. The table above provides the experimental conditions used. If both experiments are carried out with finely powdered samples of the solid and <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>50.0</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="H C l aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, which experiment, if any, will have the faster initial rate of formation of <math alttext="C O 2 gas " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and why?

choices.label: The rate of formation of <math alttext="C O 2 gas " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> will be the same because the mass of <math alttext="C a C O 3 solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and the volume of <math alttext="H C l aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> used will be the same in both experiments.

The rate of formation of <math alttext="C O 2 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> will be the same because the surface area of the solid and the average kinetic energy of the particles will be the same in both experiments.

<math alttext="C O 2 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> will be formed at a faster rate in experiment 2 because more <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> particles can react per unit time.

<math alttext="C O 2 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> will be formed at a faster rate in experiment 1 because the proportion of <math alttext="C a C O 3 solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> particles to <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> particles will be greater.

content.answer: <math alttext="C O 2 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> will be formed at a faster rate in experiment 2 because more <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> particles can react per unit time.

skill.text: 6.E: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using connections between particulate and macroscopic scales or levels.
